item.title: H*cking around
item.description: Intro People think hacking requires a great deal of skill (on the part of the attacker) and/or a great deal of skill (on the part of the defender). This is quite clearly false. There are many simple ways to exploit a system. In this post, I detail some of the times I got access to accounts I shouldn’t have been able to get access to. While these are not the specific ways that a system’s bugs are taken advantage of, in general the principles hold true.

item.title: 2FA, phishing and U2F
item.description: Intro As part of efforts to improve security, my workplace has issued us Yubikeys. What is a Yubikey? It’s a device you plug into your computer’s USB port and when you touch it for a few seconds, it spits out a string. This string is used for authentication (to identify you). The device has a capacitive sensor to detect touch, just like most phones today (old phones that used a “stylus” use resistive-touch based on resistors).
